senses.de: The act or process of convincing someone to believe in something or do something
senses.ex: The teacher used persuasion to get the students to do their homework.

Tips.title: Active Engagement
Tips.description: Persuasion involves actively engaging with someone's thoughts and feelings to influence them.
Tips.example: Through active engagement, he used persuasion to encourage his friends to recycle.

Tips.title: Emotional Appeal
Tips.description: Persuasion often appeals to emotions rather than logic, to influence decisions.
Tips.example: Her speech used strong emotional appeals for persuasion, leaving the audience moved.

Tips.title: Subtle Techniques
Tips.description: Persuasive techniques can be subtle, like using specific words that have positive connotations.
Tips.example: Advertisers use subtle persuasion in their choice of words to attract customers.

senses.de: A particular type of belief or way of thinking
senses.ex: He is of the persuasion that global warming is a serious threat to our planet.

Tips.title: Beyond Preference
Tips.description: Persuasion as a belief implies a deeper conviction than a mere preference or liking.
Tips.example: His vegan persuasion steps beyond preference, rooted in deep ethical beliefs.

Tips.title: Cultural Context
Tips.description: A person's persuasion can be influenced by cultural background, affecting their opinions and actions.
Tips.example: Due to her cultural persuasion, she places great importance on community and family.

Tips.title: Identifying Persuasion
Tips.description: When someone mentions their persuasion, they're often signaling a key aspect of their identity.
Tips.example: Introducing herself as 'of an environmental persuasion' signaled her commitment to sustainability.

Appeal.wordDefinition:
Appeal refers to a desire or emotion that attracts or interests someone.

It is used to convince or attract someone based on their personal feelings. For example, a product may appeal to someone because of its design, features, or brand recognition.

Appeal is about attracting someone's interest, while persuasion is about convincing them using reason and evidence.

Both are useful in different situations, and effective communication often involves a combination of both appeal and persuasion.

Argument.wordDefinition:
An argument is a debate or disagreement between two or more people with different opinions or beliefs. It involves presenting and defending one's own point of view while refuting the opposing views.

Argument is applicable in situations where there is a disagreement or conflict, while persuasion is applicable in situations where one wants to convince someone of something, such as in marketing, advertising, or political campaigns.

Coercion.wordDefinition:
Coercion refers to forcefully or physically making someone do something against their will, often through the use of threats, force or manipulation.

It implies that the person has no option but to comply with the demands of the person or entity applying coercion.

Coercion is often illegal and is mostly applicable in negative situations, such as when someone is being threatened or intimidated into doing something they don't want to do.

Conviction.wordDefinition:
Conviction means a strong belief or opinion about something that is not likely to change. It implies that one has made up their mind and is sure of what they believe in.

Conviction is usually used in legal settings when someone is found guilty of a crime.

Conviction refers to a strong belief that one has, while persuasion refers to trying to convince someone else to adopt that belief or take a certain action.

Conviction is applicable when one is sure of themselves, while persuasion is applicable when trying to convince others.

Influence.wordDefinition:
Influence refers to the ability to have an impact on someone's decisions or behavior without directly convincing them to do something.

For example, a celebrity might have an influence on what music or fashion people choose to follow.

Influence is something that comes naturally or over time, while persuasion is a more deliberate or intentional effort to change someone's mind or behavior.

Manipulate.wordDefinition:
Manipulation involves using deception, trickery or underhanded tactics to gain control over someone or something. It often involves taking advantage of someone's weaknesses or vulnerabilities to get them to do what you want.

Manipulation is generally considered unethical and can be harmful to the person being manipulated. Persuasion, however, can be a legitimate and effective way to communicate ideas, negotiate conflicts, and make positive changes in the world.

Rhetoric.wordDefinition:
Persuasion and rhetoric are related but have different meanings. Persuasion refers to the act of convincing someone to believe or do something.

Rhetoric is the use of language to persuade or influence an audience.

Rhetoric is often used in a more formal setting, like a speech or debate, to persuade or influence an audience. It involves the use of persuasive language and techniques like appeal to emotions or reason.

Rhetoric can also be used in writing, such as persuasive essays or advertising copy.

To sum up, persuasion is the act of convincing someone, while rhetoric is the use of persuasive language and techniques to influence an audience.

Both can be used in a variety of settings, but rhetoric is often used in formal speaking and writing contexts.

Seduce.wordDefinition:
Seduce means to try and lure someone into doing something they may not necessarily want to do through attraction, charm, manipulation or deceit.

A manipulative individual may try to seduce someone into doing something they wouldn't ordinarily do, such as cheating on a test or committing a crime.

Persuasion involves using logical or emotional appeals to convince someone to do something or believe in something, while seduction involves trying to manipulate or deceive someone into doing something for personal gain.

quotes.Text: Stories are one of the most powerful forces of persuasion available to us, especially stories that fit in with our view of what the world should be like. Facts can be contested. Stories are far trickier. I can dismiss someone's logic, but dismissing how I feel is harder.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Maria Konnikova

quotes.Text: Whether it is a tsunami, or whether it is a hurricane, whether it's an earthquake - when we see these great fatal and natural acts, men and women of every ethnic persuasion come together and they just want to help.
quotes.Title: American Activist
quotes.Name: Martin Luther King III

quotes.Text: Moral persuasion over a period of time makes a difference, but we shouldn't be naive to think that just because we raise it in a meeting it will make all those problems go away. It won't and it doesn't.
quotes.Title: New Zealander Politician
quotes.Name: John Key

quotes.Text: There are positive steps being taken to tackle issues that people from all walks of life, races, ethnicities, and political persuasions agree have been devastating to communities of color.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Cris Carter

quotes.Text: Thaw with her gentle persuasion is more powerful than Thor with his hammer. The one melts, the other breaks into pieces.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.Text: Not brute force but only persuasion and faith are the kings of this world.
quotes.Title: Scottish Philosopher
quotes.Name: Thomas Carlyle

quotes.Text: The triumph of persuasion over force is the sign of a civilized society.
quotes.Title: American Economist
quotes.Name: Mark Skousen

quotes.Text: Character may almost be called the most effective means of persuasion.
quotes.Title: Greek Philosopher
quotes.Name: Aristotle

quotes.Text: People of similar political persuasions tend to flock together.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Ben Affleck

quotes.Text: Most people don't have the power of persuasion.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: James Altucher
